note_text:
Admission Date:  [**2151-7-25**]              Discharge Date:   [**2151-7-25**]

Date of Birth:  [**2125-5-6**]             Sex:   M

Service: SURGERY

Allergies:
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs

Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 2534**]
Chief Complaint:
Multitrauma with hypotension and hypoxia

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Attempted Resuscitation with multiple blood transfusions

History of Present Illness:
26 yo male unrestrained passenger in a multi-car accident,
ejected 100 feet from vehicle, found in [**Doctor Last Name 6641**].  He was
transferred from [**Hospital 1562**] Hospital in critical condition
reported to have liver laceration, pulmonary contusion,
fractured ribs, broken arm, hypotensive and hypoxic.

Past Medical History:
Unknown

Social History:
unknown

Family History:
unknown

Physical Exam:
On arrival in the ED:
BP= 110/54, HR 138, 82% on vent
Gen: unresponsive, intubated
Neuro: Pupils equal, unresponsive No corneal reactions, no gag
or cough.  Initially decerbrate posturing with noxious stimuli,
rapidly without any response, no rectal tone
CV: tachycardic, regular rhythm
Chest: orally intubated, breath sounds wet throughout, pink
froth from ETT
Abd: abd soft, distended, no bowel sounds
MSK: obvious RUE deformity, large hematoma upper arm; massive
abrasion from shoulder to elbow; radial pulse by doppler.
Diffuse deep abrasion right flank, back, facial abrasion;
mulitple small bleeding lacerations and abrasions on face and
arms.  Left foot abrasions, left great toe laceration open to
bone.

.
X-ray chest and pelvis ([**2151-7-25**]):
1.  Generalized opacification of the right lung is most likely
related to
contusion.  A small amount of right-sided pleural effusion is
also present. Mildly increased opacity of the left lung is most
likely related to a pulmonary contusion.
2.  All the lines and tube appear in place.
3. The upper right portion of the mediastinum is widened  and
needs further evaluation by CT.
4. Multiple rib fractures on the right side.
.
CXR ([**2151-7-25**]): IMPRESSION:
1.  Proper position of the left-sided chest tube.  The remainder
of the tubes and lines are in place.
2.  Unchanged appearance of the bilateral pulmonary
opacification and widened mediastinum.


Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was a 26 year old male, unrestrained passenger
involved in a multi-car accident, ejected 100 feet from vehicle
and found in the [**Doctor Last Name 6641**].  He was resuscitated at [**Hospital 1562**]
Hospital with 6 units of PRBCs, crystalloid, intubation,
cervical stabilization and med-flighted to [**Hospital1 18**].  He presented
to the emergency room as a trauma patient at 2:00am.
.
Events: A full attempt at resuscitation was attempted in the
trauma bay with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] at the bedside.  Patient was given 6
units of blood, massive amounts of intravenous fluids, and
started on a norepinephrine drip as well as maximized on
mechanical ventilation.
.
Neuro: unresponsive throughout. Initial decerebrate posturing
diminished to no response to any stimuli.
CV: Pt was in cardiogenic shock initially responsive to massive
crystalloid, blood product resuscitiation with heart rate of
sinus tachycardia to 130's, MAP>60.  Cool dusky extremities on
arrival, feeble peripheral pulses throughout.  Norepinephrine
required to support BP, maxed to 0.5mcg/kg/min.
Pulm: Patient remained orally intubated, poor oxygenation
througthout efforts, SpO2max 79% on 100% full support.  He was
emitting bloody froth fro mETT, and suctioned for copious bloody
secretions.  He had bilateral chest tubes with right with brisk
bloody drainage, left with minimal, no air leaks bilaterally.
GI: The patient had a soft, distended abdomen with the oral
gastric tube draining bloody fluid.  He had no rectal tone.
Renal: Catheter with clear yellow urine
MSK: right upper extremity with obvious deformity; multiple
contusions, lacerations and abrasions throughout body.
.
His parents and sister were able to see the patient early during
the resuscitation effort, and periodically throughout. RC priest
gave patient his last rights.  Drs [**Last Name (STitle) **] and [**Name5 (PTitle) **] spoke with
the parents at length after 1.5 hours of resuscitation, and the
decision was made to cease efforts when the patient deteriorated
into unstable cardiac rhythm.
.
The patient expired and was pronounced dead at 04:00am. The case
was referred to the medical examiner.  The body was transported
to the [**Hospital1 18**] morgue.


Medications on Admission:
unknown

Discharge Medications:
n/a

Discharge Disposition:
Expired

Discharge Diagnosis:
Multi-trauma leading to cardiac arrest

Discharge Condition:
Expired
